fenics_mpm.model module¶

class fenics_mpm.model.Model(out_dir, grid_model, dt, verbose=True)[source]¶

Bases: object

A model which links a GridModel to a set of Materials; the material point method algorithm.

Parameters:
  • out_dir (string) – directory to save results, defalult is ./output/. Currently not used by this class.
  • grid_model (GridModel) – the finite-element model instance.
  • dt (float) – the timestep \(\Delta t\).

The instantiation of this class creates the following class variables :

  • self.grid_model – the GridModel instance for this problem
  • self.dt – the time-step \(\Delta t\) to use
  • self.materials – an initially empty list of materials
add_material(M)[source]¶

Add Material M to the list of materials self.materials.

advect_material_particles()[source]¶

First, interpolate the \(i=1,2,\ldots,n_n\) grid accelerations \(\mathbf{a}_i\) and velocities \(\mathbf{u}_i\) by the functions interpolate_grid_acceleration_to_material() and interpolate_grid_velocity_to_material() respectively. Then iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and increment the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) intermediate particle velocities \(\mathbf{u}_p^*\) and particle positions \(\mathbf{x}_p\) by the explicit forward-Euler finite-difference scheme

\[\begin{split}\mathbf{u}_p^t &= \mathbf{u}_p^{t-1} + \mathbf{a}_p \Delta t \\ \mathbf{x}_p^t &= \mathbf{x}_p^{t-1} + \mathbf{u}_p^* \Delta t.\end{split}\]
calculate_grid_acceleration()[source]¶

Calculate the \(i=1,2,\ldots,n_n\) grid acceleration vectors \(\mathbf{a}_i\) containted at self.grid_model.a3 by

\[\mathbf{a}_i = \frac{\mathbf{f}_i^{\mathrm{int}} + \mathbf{f}_i^{\mathrm{ext}}}{m_i},\]

where the grid mass \(m_i\) has been limited to be \(\geq \varepsilon = 1 \times 10^{-2}\), and external forces are currently only \(\mathbf{f}_i^{\mathrm{ext}} = \mathbf{0}\).

calculate_grid_internal_forces()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and interpolate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle stress divergence terms \(\nabla \cdot \sigma_p\) to the \(i=1,2,\ldots,n_n\) internal force vectors \(\mathbf{f}_i^{\mathrm{int}}\) containted at self.grid_model.f_int by

\[\mathbf{f}_i^{\mathrm{int}} = - \sum_{p=1}^{n_p} \nabla \phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p) \cdot \sigma_p V_p\]

This is the weak-stress-divergence volume integral.

calculate_material_initial_density()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle densities \(\rho_p\) given by M.rho by interpolating the \(i=1,2,\ldots,n_n\) nodal masses \(m_i\) and nodal cell diameter volume estimates \(v_i = \frac{4}{3} \pi \left(\frac{h_i}{2}\right)^3\) using approximate nodal cell diameter \(h_i\). That is,

\[\rho_p = \sum_{i=1}^{n_n} \phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p) \frac{m_i}{v_i}\]

Note that this is useful only for the initial density \(\rho_p^0\) calculation and aftwards should evolve thereafter with \(\rho_p = \rho_p^0 / \mathrm{det}(F_p)\).

calculate_material_initial_mass()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle masses \(m_p\) given by M.m using particle volume \(V_p\) and constant material density \(\rho\) :

\[m_p = \frac{V_p}{\rho}.\]
calculate_material_initial_volume()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle volumes \(V_p\) given by M.V from particle mass \(m_p\) and density \(\rho_p\). That is,

\[V_p = \frac{m_p}{\rho_p}.\]

Note that this is useful only for the initial particle volume \(V_p^0\) calculation and aftwards should evolve with \(V_p = V_p^0 \mathrm{det}(F_p)\). Also, this requires that the particle density be initialized by calling calculate_material_density().

calculate_material_velocity_gradient()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle velocity gradient vectors \(\nabla \mathbf{u}_p\) given by M.grad_u by interpolating the \(i=1,2,\ldots,n_n\) nodal velocity vectors \(\nabla \mathbf{u}_i\) using the grid basis function gradients evaluated at the particle position \(\nabla \phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p)\). That is,

\[\nabla \mathbf{u}_p = \sum_{i=1}^{n_n} \nabla \phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p) \mathbf{u}_i.\]
color()[source]¶
formulate_material_basis_functions()[source]¶

Iterate through each particle for each material M in list self.materials and calculate the particle interpolation function \(\phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p)\) and gradient function \(\nabla \phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p)\) values for each of the \(n_n\) nodes of the corresponding grid cell. This overwrites each Materials M.vrt, M.phi, and M.grad_phi values.

initialize_material_tensors()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle incremental deformation gradient tensors set to M.dF as

\[\mathrm{d}F_p = I + \Delta t \nabla \mathbf{u}_p\]

with particle velocity gradient \(\nabla \mathbf{u}_p\) given by M.grad_u and time-step \(\Delta t\) from self.dt; the deformation gradient tensors

\[F_p = \mathrm{d}F_p\]

set to M.F; strain-rate tensor \(\dot{\epsilon}_p\) given by calculate_strain_rate() set to M.epsilon; and Cauchy-stress tensor \(\sigma_p\) given by calculate_stress() set to M.sigma.

interpolate_grid_acceleration_to_material()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and interpolate the \(i=1,2,\ldots,n_n\) grid acceleration vectors \(\mathbf{a}_i\) to each of the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle acceleration vectors \(\mathbf{a}_p\) given by M.a. That is,

\[\mathbf{a}_p = \sum_{i=1}^{n_n} \phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p) \mathbf{a}_i\]

These particle accelerations are used to calculate the new particle velocities by advect_material_particles().

interpolate_grid_velocity_to_material()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and interpolate the \(i=1,2,\ldots,n_n\) grid velocity vectors \(\mathbf{u}_i\) to each of the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle velocity vectors \(\mathbf{u}_p^*\) given by M.u_star. That is,

\[\mathbf{u}_p^* = \sum_{i=1}^{n_n} \phi_i(\mathbf{x}_p) \mathbf{u}_i\]

Note that this is an intermediate step used by advect_material_particles().

interpolate_material_mass_to_grid()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and interpolate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle masses \(m_p\) given by M.m to the GridModel instance self.grid_model.m. That is,

\[m_i = \sum_{p=1}^{n_p} \phi_p(\mathbf{x}_p) m_p\]
interpolate_material_velocity_to_grid()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and interpolate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle velocity vectors \(\mathbf{u}_p\) given by M.u to the GridModel instance self.grid_model.U3. In order to conserve velocity, weight by particle weight fraction \(m_p / m_i\) for each \(i = 1,2,\ldots,n_n\) nodes. That is,

\[\mathbf{u}_i = \sum_{p=1}^{n_p} \frac{m_p}{m_i} \phi_p(\mathbf{x}_p) \mathbf{u}_p\]

Note that this requires that \(m_i\) be calculated by calling interpolate_material_mass_to_grid().

mpm(t_start, t_end, cb_ftn=None)[source]¶

The material point method algorithm performed from time t_start to t_end.

Parameters:
  • t_start (float) – starting time of the simulation
  • t_end (float) – ending time of the simulation
  • cb_ftn (function) – callback function

For any given time-step, the algorithm consists of:

  • formulate_material_basis_functions()
  • interpolate_material_mass_to_grid()
  • interpolate_material_velocity_to_grid()

If this is the initialization step (t == t_start):

  • initialize_material_tensors()
  • calculate_material_density()
  • calculate_material_initial_volume()

Then continue the grid calculation stage :

  • calculate_grid_internal_forces()
  • calculate_grid_acceleration()
  • update_grid_velocity()

Then the particle calculation stage :

  • calculate_material_velocity_gradient()
  • update_material_deformation_gradient()
  • update_material_volume()
  • update_material_stress()
  • interpolate_grid_acceleration_to_material()
  • interpolate_grid_velocity_to_material()
  • advect_material_particles()

At the end of the algorithm, the grid properties are made available from the C++ backend :

  • retrieve_cpp_material_properties()
  • retrieve_cpp_grid_properties()
retrieve_cpp_grid_U3()[source]¶

Get the velocity vector from C++ model self.mpm_cpp and set to self.grid_model.u and self.grid_model.v.

retrieve_cpp_grid_a3()[source]¶

Get the acceleration vector from C++ model self.mpm_cpp and set to self.grid_model.a_x and self.grid_model.a_y.

retrieve_cpp_grid_f_int()[source]¶

Get the internal force vector from C++ model self.mpm_cpp and set to self.grid_model.f_int_x and self.grid_model.f_int_y.

retrieve_cpp_grid_m()[source]¶

Get the mass vector from C++ model self.mpm_cpp and set to self.grid_model.m.

retrieve_cpp_grid_properties()[source]¶

Transfer grid properties from C++ back to python for further analysis with PyLab.

retrieve_cpp_material_properties()[source]¶

Transfer material properties from C++ back to python for further analysis with PyLab.

set_boundary_conditions()[source]¶
update_grid_velocity()[source]¶

Update the grid velocity \(\mathbf{u}_i\) located at self.grid_model.U3 from the current acceleration vector \(\mathbf{a}_i\) and time-step \(\Delta t\) from the explicit forward-Euler finite-difference scheme

\[\mathbf{u}_i^t = \mathbf{u}_i^{t-1} + \mathbf{a}_i \Delta t.\]
update_material_deformation_gradient()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and update the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle incremental deformation gradient tensors set to M.dF as

\[\mathrm{d}F_p = I + \left( \nabla \mathbf{u}_p \right) \Delta t \]

with particle velocity gradient \(\nabla \mathbf{u}_p\) given by M.grad_u and time-step \(\Delta t\) from self.dt; and update the deformation gradient tensors

\[F_p^t = \mathrm{d}F_p \circ F_p^{t-1}\]

set to M.F. Here, \(\circ\) is the element-wise Hadamard product.

update_material_density()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle densities from the incremental particle deformation gradient tensors \(\mathrm{d}F_p\) given by M.dF at the previous time-step \(t-1\) from the formula

\[\rho_p^t = \mathrm{det}(\mathrm{d}F_p)^{-1} \rho_p^{t-1}.\]

This is equivalent to the operation

\[V_p^t = \mathrm{det}(F_p)^{-1} \rho_p^0,\]

with particle deformation gradient tensor \(F_p\) given by M.F and initial density \(\rho_p^0\) calculated by calculate_material_initial_density() and set to M.rho0.

update_material_stress()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) incremental particle strain rate tensors \(\dot{\epsilon}_p^*\) returned by calculate_strain_rate(); then use these incremental strain rates to update the particle strain-rate tensors M.epsilon by the explicit forward-Euler finite-difference scheme

\[\dot{\epsilon}_p^t = \dot{\epsilon}_p^{t-1} + \dot{\epsilon}_p^* \Delta t \]

with time-step \(\Delta t\) from self.dt. This updated strain-rate tensor is then used to update the material stress \(\sigma_p\) by calculate_stress().

update_material_volume()[source]¶

Iterate through each M Materials in self.materials and calculate the \(p=1,2,\ldots,n_p\) particle volumes from the incremental particle deformation gradient tensors \(\mathrm{d}F_p\) given by M.dF at the previous time-step \(t-1\) from the formula

\[V_p^t = \mathrm{det}(\mathrm{d}F_p) V_p^{t-1}.\]

This is equivalent to the operation

\[V_p^t = \mathrm{det}(F_p) V_p^0,\]

with particle deformation gradient tensor \(F_p\) given by M.F and initial volume \(V_p^0\) calculated by calculate_material_initial_volume() and set to M.V0.
